quote: I use AI for search pretty much daily, looking up different questions around recipes or really anything that comes up that I'm curious about, like random facts, health-related topics, ingredients, and food.
I'm often wondering if certain things are toxic or unhealthy. A lot of my questions are health-related.
I've used AI for trip planning, mostly to look up itineraries and get suggestions for the top things to do, places to see, or places to eat.

if I have a very specific question, like, "Is rice healthier when it's refrigerated?" I might get mixed answers or it will show different articles that have different opinions. Sometimes, it doesn't always make the answer clear, and it can even provide a wrong answer citing an incorrect source.
I definitely have to take the results with a grain of salt.

So many different items come up, and I find myself having to manually create lists, prioritize, and sort them. Then I have to go through all these different tools to create various tasks and stories, and it all just feels scattered.
I think AI right now is still so dispersed, which really inhibits its ability to be productive when there's not one connected solution.
If I had the perfect AI assistant, it would easily track my to-do list, prioritize it, and help check off those items throughout the day.
I receive hundreds of emails a day, and it takes a long time to sort through them all and know what actually requires action.
being able to flag that, rank it, and sort it would be really helpful.
I was impressed with the follow-up questions. It really seemed like it was able to understand my responses and then have a pretty good follow-up question to those responses.
you just can't replace human connection and a smile on someone's face. It's how we're wired and have evolved to need human connection
I think it could ultimately be soul-sucking in the long term as it becomes more and more prevalent.
